metadata.sermon_start_end: I of course do not know what you have been doing at First Church for two hundred and seventy-five years. But I can guess, because I know a little about churches: You have been singing and praying; You have been caring and loving; You have been eating together [...] We are not our own. The one to whom we belong blesses and breaks ... and gives and gives and gives and gives!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific pericope. It treats the 'four verbs' as a biblical keyword or idea synthesized from three different texts (Paul and two Markan feedings). It does not ask what is in the specific text that can be found nowhere else; instead, it seeks a common denominator across Scripture, which Dekker explicitly forbids.
quotes: I read to you the 'words of institution' from Paul... I read the gospel story of Jesus about the five loaves... And in Mark 8, in a second feeding wonder...
In every case it says, he took the bread, he blessed it/or gave thanks for it, he broke it, and he gave it to his disciples.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Markan feeding or the Pauline institution and explore its unique literary and theological context rather than harmonizing them into a general 'pattern'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no exposition of the original context. The preacher does not address the historical situation of the Corinthian church or the specific messianic expectations in Mark. The 'four verbs' are treated as timeless liturgical categories rather than historically situated actions. No evidence of Greek/Hebrew study is present.
quotes: Jesus has been doing that forever in the church...
They know the simple math. But that is all they know...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Explain the significance of the 'twelve' and 'seven' baskets in their Jewish and Gentile contexts respectively, and what 'blessing' meant in a first-century Jewish meal.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part but remains somewhat sociological. It identifies the 'zeitgeist' of American capitalism and self-sufficiency. However, it often leans toward general truths about 'the world' versus 'the church' rather than concrete congregational life.
quotes: These moves run against the grain of American capitalism. They run against the grain of affluent self-competence.
First Church will continue the struggle about its downtown location, about its aging membership, about access to the basement...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond the 'countercultural' trope to specific ethical or spiritual demands this text places on the hearer today.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a thematic structure (the four verbs) where application and description are mixed, which Dekker favors. However, because the 'exposition' is so thin, the 'interweaving' feels more like a thematic lecture than a text-driven movement.
quotes: This verb 'take' is a confession among us in the church, that Jesus claims our lives...
Jesus breaks our life so that we are not our own but we belong to him...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the text's own narrative tension (e.g., the disciples' misunderstanding in the boat) to drive the contemporary application.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories are present in the background. 'Misery' is identified as the self-sufficient life leading to alienation. 'Redemption' is Christ's claiming of the life. 'Gratitude' is the transformed life of joy. However, it risks being too 'objective'—the human subject's inner struggle with sin is replaced by a critique of 'culture'.
quotes: When we go under our own steam, that leads to weariness, cynicism, despair, apathy...
Jesus blesses our life and infuses it with power, meaning, and joy.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by addressing the 'hard hearts' mentioned in the text as a present reality for the believer, not just 'the world'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present in the contrast between the 'countercultural' church and the 'alienated' world. The sermon warns that the world's way 'inevitably ends in alienation and violence'. However, the 'eternal' dimension is absent, and the choice feels more like a lifestyle preference than a matter of life and death.
quotes: We refuse the self-oriented, self-sufficient life of the world that inevitably ends in alienation and violence.
The world is about to run out of its own resources; soon or late it will want to know if there is an alternative.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the gravity of 'not understanding' (Mark 8:21) as a form of being lost in time, as Dekker suggests.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos and the active subject of the four verbs. The sermon emphasizes that salvation is 'outside' man—it is Jesus who takes, breaks, and gives. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the 'miraculous center of power' found in the human Jesus.
quotes: Jesus takes, he does not ask, he takes what we have, because he acts as Lord.
Man has no life in himself... we belong to our faithful savior Jesus Christ.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'broken bread' to the atonement (the cross) more substantively than a passing mention.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 15 minutes (1550 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker’s 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth', resulting in a repetitive thematic structure rather than a deep exegetical dive.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the exegetical weight and historical-theological reflection to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its lack of a specific pericope and its thin exegetical foundation. It functions more as a thematic meditation on a liturgical pattern ('the four verbs') than an exposition of God's Word. While it successfully identifies the zeitgeist of self-sufficiency and maintains a Christocentric focus, it lacks the 'breadth' and 'specificity' that Dekker demands.
strengths: Christocentric focus where Jesus is the active subject of the verbs.
Clear identification of the contemporary idol of 'self-competence'.
Effective use of the 'three parts' (misery/redemption/gratitude) as a background framework.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific Bible passage; it harmonizes multiple texts into a general idea.
Insufficient length and depth; at 15 minutes, it remains on the surface of the 'four moves'.
Absence of original language study or historical-critical exposition.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about a biblical idea' rather than a 'sermon' in Dekker's strict sense. It lacks the specific exegetical rigor and the focus on a single pericope necessary to be a form of the Word of God.
